posts.name:
Walter Crosby
Walter Crosby
posts.content:
Do you want to improve the performance of your team? 

Your team might be a leadership team, a sales team, an operations team, a sports team, or even a family.

My friend and colleague Nate Tutas of Mind Vault discussed a simple formula for you to follow.

Performance = Potential – Interference. With anyone, it is helping them understand what is getting in their way of doing the activity, changing the behavior, or adjusting the mindset.

This episode is the start of a new series for you to learn about coaching and leading a team!

You can listen to the episode here 

Go grab a cocktail, a cigar and strap in for another great episode of Sales and Cigars.
posts.commentAdded: Great insights, Nate! Understanding and addressing interference is key to unlocking team potential. Looking forward to the series!

posts.name:
Matthew Buchalski
Matthew Buchalski
posts.content:
One of the hardest things to master as a leader is finding the balance between celebrating progress and relentlessly striving for better.

And this is more difficult than most people realize.

Leaders are hardwired to look ahead.

They are constantly hunting for the next opportunity, pushing for innovation, and setting new performance benchmarks.

It is what makes them driven and ambitious, but sometimes, it is also what makes them miss the moment.

I will be the first to admit, I struggle with this.

At work, I am always asking, "What is next? How can we improve? Where is the next win?"

And while this mindset drives results, it can sometimes overlook an important reality: progress matters, and so does recognizing it.

This tendency does not just stay at the office.

It follows me home.

My family points it out all the time.

It’s hard for me to switch gears and detach from the instinct to set higher standards and aim for better outcomes.

But family is not the same as business.

And honestly, neither is business all the time.

Leaders need to make intentional efforts to pause, take a breath, and recognize progress, not just for themselves, but for their teams.

Why?

Because being present and showing appreciation for the milestones, big or small, fuels motivation and reinforces a culture of achievement.

When you acknowledge progress, you are not just patting people on the back.

You are showing them that their hard work matters and that they are moving the needle.

Here is the takeaway from all of this:

Being results-driven is great, but do not let it come at the cost of being present.

Take a moment to celebrate the progress, recognize the wins, and let your team (or your family) know that you see them.

So, ask yourself: When was the last time you acknowledged progress before moving on to the next goal?
posts.commentAdded: Such a valuable reminder! Celebrating progress fuels motivation and strengthens team culture. Lets embrace the moment and recognize our wins!
